item.title: If You Think This Instrument Is Hard to Play, Try Building One
item.description: The oboe has 500 parts. Turning a profit is a killer. But Jim Phelan is bent on reviving one of the great names in classical music.
item.dc:creator: Jesse Green and Jonah Rosenberg
item.media:credit: Jonah Rosenberg for The New York Times

item.title: Tony Dokoupil’s Road Trip on CBS News Hits a Rough Patch
item.description: A stretch of big news revealed growing pains for CBS’s new evening anchor and problems with its Bari Weiss-era philosophy.
item.dc:creator: James Poniewozik
item.media:credit: CBS Evening News
item.media:description: Tony Dokoupil, the new anchor of “CBS Evening News,” interviewed President Trump in a factory near Detroit on Tuesday night. Dokoupil has been broadcasting from different cities since his debut last week.

item.title: Harper Lee Expanded on Her View of the South in Letters to a Friend
item.description: In decades of correspondence, the author gave her friend, JoBeth McDaniel, a mix of opinions, advice on writing and insight into the impact of the Civil Rights movement.
item.dc:creator: Colin Moynihan
item.media:credit: Alamy
item.media:description: Harper Lee in a photograph taken by her friend Truman Capote. Taken in 1960, it was used on the dust jacket of the first edition of her novel “To Kill a Mockingbird.”

item.title: Jodie Foster: An American Oscar-Winner in Paris
item.description: In “A Private Life,” the actress takes on her first solo lead role in which she speaks fluent French, but her French connection goes all the way back to childhood.
item.dc:creator: Elaine Sciolino and Benjamin Malapris
item.media:description: To prepare for her role in ”A Private Life,” Foster read French books aloud at home and then turned up in Paris to immerse herself in French life.

item.title: The Art of a Good Awards-Show Speech
item.description: Demi Moore nailed it at last year’s Globes, and so did Teyana Taylor this year. The best acceptances keep in mind four key guidelines.
item.dc:creator: Kyle Buchanan

item.title: Want Your MTV? A Rogue Site Is Bringing Back the Videos.
item.description: The unofficial website MTV Rewind has recreated the channel’s classic era, pulling in thousands of clips. Its developer says it’s an antidote to the algorithms.
item.dc:creator: David Browne

item.title: The Kid Mero, Now a Morning-Radio Motormouth
item.description: The podcast star from the Bronx is taking over the marquee a.m. slot on New York’s storied hip-hop station Hot 97. We rode along on his first day.
item.dc:creator: Jon Caramanica
item.media:credit: Michael Tyrone Delaney for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Kid Mero at work on his first day as Hot 97’s new morning host.

item.title: In ‘Sound of Falling,’ a House Full of Secrets
item.description: Mascha Schilinski’s movie “Sound of Falling,” which takes place over a century in a rural farmhouse, shows how trauma is transmitted through generations.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Rogers

item.title: In ‘Ponies,’ Emilia Clarke Is Done With Dragons
item.description: The “Game of Thrones” actress plays a fledgling spy in “Ponies,” a Cold-War era drama that takes her career in a new direction.
item.dc:creator: Imogen West-Knights and Charlotte Hadden
item.media:credit: Charlotte Hadden for The New York Times

item.title: Kiefer Sutherland Is Arrested After Assaulting Ride-Share Driver, Police Say
item.description: The actor also made “criminal threats” toward the driver, according to the Los Angeles police.
item.dc:creator: Matt Stevens
item.media:credit: Aude Guerrucci/Reuters
item.media:description: Kiefer Sutherland was released from custody after posting a $50,000 bond, according to county jail records available online.

item.title: Smithsonian Submits More Records in Face of Trump Deadline
item.description: The institution, which is viewed as independent, has sought to reduce tensions with the White House by complying with some of its demands for documents.
item.dc:creator: Robin Pogrebin and Graham Bowley
item.media:credit: Annabelle Gordon/Reuters
item.media:description: The Smithsonian turned over more records to comply with a White House effort to audit its content. But it’s unclear if that was enough to appease the Trump administration.

item.title: How Readers Voted on 17 Ways to Improve New York City
item.description: The top suggestions include spending more of the city’s budget on parks and libraries and fixing the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway.
item.dc:creator: Michael Kimmelman
item.media:credit: Daniel Arnold

item.title: Ricky Gervais’s Golden Globe Win for His Stand-Up Special Sends a Bad Message
item.description: That “Ricky Gervais: Mortality” won for best comedy sends a message about the lack of respect given to stand-up.
item.dc:creator: Jason Zinoman

item.title: The New Museum Sets Reopening Date With New Artist Commissions
item.description: After over three years of construction, the museum will open its new building on March 21 with an ambitious show exploring how technologies have changed what it means to be human.
item.dc:creator: Zachary Small
item.media:credit: Tony Cenicola/The New York Times
item.media:description: The 60,000-square-foot expansion to the New Museum, right, knits together the two buildings. The museum reopens on March 21 to the public; admission will be free that weekend.

item.title: Frank Dunlop, 98, Dies; Director Who Gave Theater a Free-Spirited Spin
item.description: In 1970, he founded London’s Young Vic, an adventurous “people’s theater” (the Who took the stage at one point) before shaking up the Brooklyn Academy of Music.
item.dc:creator: Alex Williams
item.media:credit: Evening Standard, via Getty Images
item.media:description: The theater director and company leader Frank Dunlop in 1977. “Ideas, plans, suggestions issue from him like lava,” one critic said.

item.title: Rebecca Kilgore, 76, Dies; Acclaimed Interpreter of American Songbook
item.description: An elegant jazz singer with adventurous taste, she counted among her fans the performer Michael Feinstein and the songwriter Dave Frishberg, who called her technique “flawless.”
item.dc:creator: Adam Bernstein
item.media:credit: Brian Foskett, via National Jazz Archive -- Heritage Images/Getty Images
item.media:description: Rebecca Kilgore performing in 2007. “My goal,” she said, “is that when someone hears me sing a song, they say, ‘Wow, what a beautiful song,’ rather than, ‘Wow, what a great singer.’”

item.title: Leonardo DiCaprio Is Honored at Annual National Board of Review Gala
item.description: The stars were honored at the annual National Board of Review gala, where winners called attention to protests in Minneapolis and the violent crackdown in Iran.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Bahr and Nina Westervelt
item.category: National Board of Review of Motion Pictures
If I Had Legs I'd Kick You (Movie)
item.media:credit: Nina Westervelt for The New York Times

item.title: Applying Richard Foreman’s Off-Kilter Aesthetic (and Ducks) to Opera
item.description: The composer Michael Gordon collaborated with Foreman on “What to Wear” in 2006. The opera makes its belated New York premiere at BAM on Thursday.
item.dc:creator: Elisabeth Vincentelli
item.media:credit: George Etheredge for The New York Times

item.title: Jim McBride Dies at 78; Brought Honky-Tonk Back to Country Music
item.description: He was best known for his long-running collaboration with Alan Jackson and their signature hit, “Chattahoochee.”
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen

item.title: Inside an Exploding Marriage: Belle Burden in Her Own Words
item.description: After 20 years, Belle Burden’s picture-perfect marriage came crashing down when her husband suddenly walked away.
item.dc:creator: Anna Martin
item.media:credit: Photo Illustration by The New York Times; Background: Brian Rea; Inset photo: Victor Llorente for The New York Times

item.title: Stephen Colbert Accuses Trump of ‘Invading Minnesota’
item.description: “Has anyone told him that they don’t have oil?” Colbert said of the president’s plan to send 1,000 more immigration officers to Minnesota.
item.dc:creator: Trish Bendix
item.category: Late Show with Stephen Colbert (TV Program)
Late Night with Seth Meyers (TV Program)

item.title: Jimmy Carter, the Man From Plains, Had a Passion for Painting
item.description: Amy Carter, the daughter of former president Jimmy Carter, selected paintings and memorabilia for two Christie’s sales. The prices might surprise you.
item.dc:creator: Zachary Small

item.title: BTS Unveils 2026-27 World Tour Dates. Here’s Where The K-Pop Stars Have Been.
item.description: The K-pop superstars will go on a colossal comeback tour: 79 shows across five continents in 11 months. But why were they gone for so long?
item.dc:creator: Adeel Hassan
item.media:credit: Yoan Valat/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: BTS performing in Paris in 2018 during an event that was part of the South Korean president’s official visit to France.

item.title: Review: Boston Symphony Can’t Make the Case for Barber’s ‘Vanessa’
item.description: Performing “Vanessa” is just what the Boston Symphony should be doing. But its concert staging came off as drab and ineffective.
item.dc:creator: David Allen

item.title: 7 Albums I’m Looking Forward to in 2026
item.description: Megan Moroney, Bruno Mars, Danny L Harle and more.
item.dc:creator: Lindsay Zoladz
item.media:credit: Seth Herald/Reuters
item.media:description: Megan Moroney

item.title: After Sudden Loss, Park Avenue Armory Hires New Artistic Leader
item.description: Deborah Warner, known for directing theater and opera, succeeds Pierre Audi, who died last year. Her own work is expected to be part of her programming.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Barone
item.media:credit: Graham Dickie for The New York Times
item.media:description: Warner’s work includes “The Angel Project,” from the early 2000s, an interdisciplinary journey across vacant spaces in New York.

item.title: Scott Adams, Creator of the Satirical ‘Dilbert’ Comic Strip, Dies at 68
item.description: His chronicles of a corporate cubicle dweller was widely distributed until racist comments on his podcast led newspapers to cut their ties with him.
item.dc:creator: Richard Sandomir
item.media:credit: Lea Suzuki/The San Francisco Chronicle, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Scott Adams in 2014 in his home office in Pleasanton, Calif. For more than 30 years, his comic strip, “Dilbert,” chronicled the absurdities of the high-tech workplace and skewered management.

item.title: Adrien Brody and Tessa Thompson to Star in ‘Fear of 13’ on Broadway
item.description: The play, about a man who spends decades on death row before being exonerated by DNA evidence, will have a 16-week run this spring.
item.dc:creator: Michael Paulson
item.media:credit: From left: Mario Anzuoni/Reuters; Caroline Brehman/Reuters
item.media:description: “The Fear of 13,” featuring Adrien Brody and Tessa Thompson, will begin previews March 19 at the James Earl Jones Theater.

item.title: 130 Tracks of Guitar Per Song? Sunn O))) Is Back, and Going Big.
item.description: The hard-to-categorize duo recorded its new, self-titled album surrounded by nature. It’ll be the band’s first on the storied Seattle label Sub Pop.
item.dc:creator: Hank Shteamer

item.title: Karl Ove Knausgaard’s Books: A Guide
item.description: The Norwegian writer is known for his sprawling, brutally candid autofiction and speculative epics. Here’s where to start.
item.dc:creator: Adam Dalva
item.category: In the Land of the Cyclops: Essays (Book)
item.media:credit: Photo by Michael Nagle for The New York Times

item.title: Jon Stewart Skewers Trump as ‘Acting President of Venezuela’
item.description: “Doesn’t your oath of office to America have a noncompete?” the “Daily Show” host asked President Trump.
item.dc:creator: Trish Bendix
item.category: Late Show with Stephen Colbert (TV Program)
Late Night with Seth Meyers (TV Program)
The Daily Show with Jon Stewart (TV Program)

item.title: Leaders of Historians’ Group Veto Resolutions Critical of Israel
item.description: The executive council of the American Historical Association said the resolutions, including one accusing Israel of ‘scholasticide’ in Gaza, would put the group at risk.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Schuessler
item.media:credit: Natalie Keyssar for The New York Times

item.title: Dan Bongino, No Longer at the F.B.I., Will Return to Podcasting
item.description: The former F.B.I. deputy director, who had hosted a right-wing, pro-Trump podcast, will restart the show after a rocky tenure at the law-enforcement agency.
item.dc:creator: Reggie Ugwu
item.media:credit: Jason Koerner/Getty Images
item.media:description: As the deputy director of the F.B.I., Dan Bongino took part in investigations that debunked claims he had earlier made in his work as a podcaster.

item.title: L.A. Reid Settles Lawsuit Shortly Before Sexual Assault Trial
item.description: Mr. Reid, a Grammy-winning music producer, had been accused of assaulting an executive who worked for him and then retaliating against her.
item.dc:creator: Michaela Towfighi
item.media:credit: Fred Prouser/Reuters
item.media:description: L.A. Reid was accused in a lawsuit of groping, kissing and digitally penetrating Drew Dixon without her consent.

item.title: 8 Stars Nikki Glaser Roasted in Her Golden Globes Monologue
item.description: The comedian, who hosted the awards ceremony for the second year in a row on Sunday, began by turning her wit mostly toward the men in the room.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor
item.media:credit: Kevork Djansezian/CBS Broadcasting, via Associated Press
item.media:description: During her opening monologue, Nikki Glaser thanked the “Pitt” and “E.R.” actor Noah Wyle for being “the only doctor I’ve seen regularly for the past last 35 years.”

item.title: Review: ‘Collage Revisited’ at Live Artery Festival
item.description: The company revived and revised a work that juxtaposes formal movement with a sound score that incorporates recordings of the 1979 White Night riots in San Francisco.
item.dc:creator: Brian Seibert
item.category: Jones, Bill T/Arnie Zane Dance Co

item.title: ‘Tehran’ Review: Israel vs. Iran, Retold as a Spy Thriller
item.description: The third season of the Israeli series, rescheduled amid the recent surge of conflicts in the Middle East, finally premieres on Apple TV.
item.dc:creator: Mike Hale
item.media:credit: Apple TV
item.media:description: Niv Sultan plays a Mossad agent embedded in Iran in “Tehran.”

item.title: Photos: Backstage With Teyana Taylor, Owen Cooper and More Golden Globe Winners
item.description: Rose Byrne, Owen Cooper, Seth Rogen, Teyana Taylor and other award winners in the spotlight.
item.dc:creator: Chantal Anderson
item.media:credit: Chantal Anderson for The New York Times

item.title: Nikki Glaser’s Monologue, Teyana Taylor’s Speech and Other Moments From the 2026 Globes
item.description: Nikki Glaser returned as host and killed, while Teyana Taylor delivered the speech of the night. Then there were those awful production choices.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Goodman
item.media:credit: Kevork Djansezian/CBS Broadcasting, via Associated Press
item.media:description: As Nikki Glaser served as Golden Globes host on Sunday night, her previous experience in the role paid off.

item.title: Ricky Gervais Won the Comedy Award. Wanda Sykes Got the Last Laugh.
item.description: Although Gervais has hosted the Golden Globes five times, he was not at the ceremony on Sunday night.
item.dc:creator: Marc Tracy

item.title: Follow Ian McKellen Into the Mixed Reality Future in ‘An Ark’
item.description: Audiences can embark on a very different type of theatrical experience in a new play at the Shed, blending the physical world with digital content.
item.dc:creator: Roslyn Sulcas

item.title: Richard Marx Is No Softy
item.description: The singer and songwriter who struck it big in the MTV era has a new take on the Great American Songbook — and a lot of wickedly funny revelations about his life.
item.dc:creator: Rob Tannenbaum and Jamie Lee Taete
item.media:credit: Jamie Lee Taete for The New York Times

item.title: ‘Tell Me Lies,’ Plus 8 Things to Watch on TV This Week
item.description: The college-set drama returns and a “Game of Thrones” prequel premieres.
item.dc:creator: Shivani Gonzalez
item.media:credit: Ian Watson/Disney
item.media:description: Jackson White and Grace Van Patten in “Tell Me Lies.”

item.title: Nikki Glaser Ended the Golden Globes by Honoring Rob Reiner
item.description: In a “Spinal Tap” baseball cap, Glaser concluded the ceremony by saying, “This one went to 11.”
item.dc:creator: Matt Stevens
item.media:credit: Evan Agostini/Invision, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Rob Reiner and Michele Singer Reiner, shown in 2013, were killed last month.

item.media:credit: Agata Grzybowska/Focus Features, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Jessie Buckley, left, and Paul Mescal in a scene from “Hamnet.”

item.title: ‘One Battle After Another’ Wins Golden Globe for Best Comedy
item.description: The victory cements the film’s front-runner status heading into the Oscars.
item.dc:creator: Esther Zuckerman
item.media:credit: Warner Bros. Pictures, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Leonardo DiCaprio as the former radical Bob in “One Battle After Another.”

item.title: Jessie Buckley Wins Golden Globe for ‘Hamnet’ as Best Actress, Motion Picture Drama
item.description: In her first nomination, Buckley won for her portrayal of Agnes, William Shakespeare’s grieving wife in the drama “Hamnet.”
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor
item.media:credit: Agata Grzybowska/Focus Features, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Jessie Buckley, center, in a scene from “Hamnet.”

item.title: ‘The Studio’ wins best TV comedy.

item.media:description: From left, Ike Barinholtz, Kathryn Hahn, Seth Rogen and Chase Sui Wonders in “The Studio.”

item.title: ‘Adolescence’ Wins Golden Globe for Best Limited Series, Marking a Triumph for Owen Cooper
item.description: Netflix’s harrowing series about a 13-year-old British boy accused of killing a girl in his school became an immediate global hit last year.
item.dc:creator: Michaela Towfighi

item.title: ‘The Pitt’ wins best TV drama.
item.dc:creator: Michaela Towfighi
item.media:credit: Warrick Page/HBO Max, via Associated Press
item.media:description: “The Pitt” previously won Emmy and Critics Choice awards for best drama.

item.title: Rhea Seehorn wins best actress in a TV drama for ‘Pluribus.’
item.dc:creator: Austin Considine

item.title: Nikki Glaser Doesn’t Spare CBS News in 2026 Golden Globes Monologue
item.description: For her second consecutive year as host, Glaser delivered a killer set of rapid-fire, very short jokes.
item.dc:creator: Jason Zinoman
item.media:credit: Kevork Djansezian/CBS Broadcasting, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Nikki Glaser returned for a second year as host of the Globes.

item.title: Timothée Chalamet Wins Best Actor at the Golden Globes for ‘Marty Supreme’
item.description: The actor won for his role in “Marty Supreme.” After five Golden Globe nominations, this is Chalamet’s first win.
item.dc:creator: Emmanuel Morgan

item.title: Rose Byrne wins best actress, motion picture musical or comedy.
item.description: Byrne won for “If I Had Legs I’d

item.title: Owen Cooper of ‘Adolescence’ wins best supporting TV actor.
item.description: He prevailed in a battle of the breakout stars of 2025 over Tramell Tillman, of Apple TV’s mind-bending sci-fi thriller “Severance.”
item.dc:creator: Jeremy Egner
item.media:credit: Netflix, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Owen Cooper previously won an Emmy and a Critics Choice award for his performance in “Adolescence.”

item.title: Golden Globes 2026 Photos: Stars of ‘Hamnet,’ ‘One Battle After Another’ and More
item.description: Our photographer is capturing behind-the-scenes moments with stars at Sunday night’s awards show.

item.media:description: Jason Bateman, Will Arnett, Alex Cooper, Sean Hayes and Mel Robbins at a SiriusXM event in Los Angeles on Saturday.

item.title: Where’s the best original score award? Not on the telecast.

item.media:description: The Globe for best score will be handed out at the ceremony but not be televised.
